title: 113_s2792
content: The "Apprenticeship and Jobs Training Act of 2014" may provide a tax credit for apprenticeship programs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Apprenticeship and Jobs Training Act of 2014" offers a tax credit for employers with qualified individuals in apprenticeship programs. The credit is the lesser of wages paid or $5,000 per individual. The tax credit is available for employers with qualified individuals in apprenticeship programs, based on the apprenticeship participation average. No double benefit is allowed. The tax credit for apprenticeship programs does not allow for double benefits, and the credit is limited to 3 taxable years for each qualified individual. Additionally, individuals must be participating in a qualified apprenticeship program with an employer to be considered a qualified individual. The tax credit for apprenticeship programs is limited to 3 taxable years for each qualified individual who meets specific criteria, including being employed under a valid apprenticeship agreement for at least 7 months, not being a highly compensated employee, and not being a seasonal worker. Employers can also consider relevant training received by members of the armed forces in the program. The term 'qualified apprenticeship program' refers to an apprenticeship program that provides on-the-job training and instruction for a qualified occupation, including relevant training received by individuals serving in the Armed Forces. The term 'qualified apprenticeship program' involves job training and instruction for a skilled trade with the employer, registered with the Office of Apprenticeship, maintaining records as prescribed by the Secretary, and meeting additional requirements set by the Secretary. The term 'qualified occupation' refers to a skilled trade in high-demand fields like healthcare or technology. An 'apprenticeship agreement' is a contract between a qualified individual and an employer that meets specific criteria. If an employer fails to fulfill obligations under an apprenticeship agreement, a qualified individual can transfer completed training to a new employer. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to implement this provision. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new apprenticeship program expenses credit as part of the general business credit. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new apprenticeship program expenses credit under section 45S. Conforming amendments are made to sections 280C(a) and 41(b)(2)(D) of the Code. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit an evaluation report on the activities related to the apprenticeship program credit. The House of Representatives will evaluate the effectiveness of the apprenticeship program credit under section 45S of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This evaluation will include the completion rates of qualified individuals in apprenticeship programs, their employment status post-apprenticeship, retention in the same occupation or field, and recommendations for program improvement. The amendments made by this Act will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. SEC. 3. ENCOURAGING MENTORS TO TRAIN THE FUTURE. SEC. 3. ENCOURAGING MENTORS TO TRAIN THE FUTURE. Amends Section 72(t)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow early distributions from qualified retirement plans to employees serving as mentors aged 55 and above who are still employed. The text chunk discusses the eligibility criteria for employees aged 55 and above to receive early distributions from qualified retirement plans if they have reduced their hours of employment to engage in mentoring activities related to their area of expertise. The text chunk amends the distribution rules for pension plans to allow distributions to employees aged 62 or older who are still working or serving as mentors. The text chunk limits distributions to mentors under certain conditions in pension plans. The text chunk limits distributions to mentors in pension plans based on a formula involving reduced hours of employment and mentoring activities. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to allow distributions to employees serving as mentors. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2014.
